Dear Lindsey Lassanske:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the violations
identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The corrective action plan is
due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result in
compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact me. In
any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an acceptable
corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any questions. In
the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone immediately, please contact
the area manager, Shay Mavis at 269-243-2725.
Sincerely,
Lonia Perry Calloway, Licensing Consultant

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation
Section
Description
1

(1) Upon receipt of any information that relates to possible
noncompliance with any foster home rule, the agency must do all
the following:
(b) Initiate a special evaluation of the foster home as soon as is
indicated, based on the information received, but not later than 7
calendar days after receipt of the information.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation.
Type
Allegation The agency was aware that the foster parents were allowing a
child to sleep in a basement bedroom which did not meet licensing
standards, and the agency did not initiate a special investigation,
nor submit for a variance to the rule.
Investigation Interviews:
On 6/10/2025 I spoke with Division of Child Welfare Licensing
Analyst (DCWLA) by telephone related to the allegations.
DCWLA confirmed the information in the complaint. She reported
the agency was aware Child A (age 2) was sleeping in a living
area in the basement of the family’s new home as a bedroom, and
the room does not meet bedroom compliance, per the foster home
licensing rules. DCWLA reported the agency’s licensing worker
assessed the foster home on 5/12/2025 and told the family the
space was okay for the child to use as a bedroom. DCWLA
reported there is no door directly leaving in and out of the room;
that the entrance to the garage is used as an entrance, which
enters a mudroom; and the mudroom enters directly into the
child’s room. Additionally, this room as a bedroom does not
ensure rest and privacy for the child; and does not have the
required items permitting it as a bedroom, such as closet, and
dresser. DCWLA also reported that pending the agency getting a
variance submitted and approved, the current safety plan is for
Child A to sleep in the room with his brother. The latter is
reportedly where Child A slept previously.
On 6/12/2025 I interviewed Chief Administrator (CA) about the
allegations by telephone. CA reported Foster 2 is an architect and
the family is residing in a new home Foster Parent 2 designed.
That, with respect to the complaint, the issue seems to be around
a garage door, and where the child is sleeping. CA reported
based on Licensing Worker’s assessment of the foster home
rules, the room in question, how the home is set up, Licensing
Worker assessed that the room was appropriate for the child to
use as a bedroom. CA reported the foster parents’ garage was
not being utilized and Licensing Worker believed the room met all
licensing requirements. CA reported the foster care staff was
2

aware of the child’s sleeping quarters, and all felt it was okay. CA
reported the child was originally sleeping in a bedroom with his
sibling, but the sibling was keeping this child up and Foster Parent
1 and Foster Parent 2 moved the child to enable him to get rest.
CA reported the family is willing to install a door, but that was not
considered in discussion with DCWL (Division of Child Welfare
Licensing) Manager, whom the agency had gone back and forth
with over this matter, and a variance being needed. CA reported
the variance has already been submitted.
On 6/17/2025, I interviewed Licensing Supervisor (LS) about the
allegations by telephone. LS reported Licensing Worker was
aware of Foster Parent 1’s and Foster Parent 2’s sleeping
arrangement for Child A prior to DCWL indicating a concern with
that arrangement. LS reported that Licensing Worker had received
a call from either Foster Parent 1 or Foster Parent 2 who
explained that Child A’s brother, Child B (age 3), whom Child A
had shared a room with, was causing sleeping difficulties for Child
A, and they wanted to move Child A into the basement area. LS
reported that the basement area is fully furnished, and the
Licensing Worker inquired of the foster parent whether the room
the foster parents were moving Child A to had a required smoke
detector, space for Child A’s clothing, a closet, means of egress
and allowed for privacy; and Licensing Worker was advised it did.
LS acknowledged that Licensing Worker did not advise Foster
Parent 1 and Foster Parent 2 she needed to come out to view the
room/area so as to ensure the room/area met licensing
requirements. LS reported Licensing Worker had recently gone to
the foster family’s home for their licensing reevaluation. Licensing
Worker had knowledge of the room. LS reported Licensing Worker
was aware that the room was off from a mudroom and Licensing
Worker had deemed the room appropriate. LS reported DCWL’s
concern seems to be that this basement room, which can be
accessed from a door from the garage, does not meet foster
parent rules’ privacy requirements. LS reported Foster Parent 1
and Foster Parent 2 had recently built this home; and the garage
is not the entryway into the home. He reported he/the agency
does not fully understand DCWL Analyst’s assessment of this
situation; and that they had gone back and forth with her over this
matter. He reported in the future, if the agency sees something
like this room situation, the agency will request a variance for the
bedroom. He reported a special evaluation on Foster Parent 1’s
and Foster Parent 2’s foster home, around this matter, had since
been opened.
3

On 6/17/2025 I interviewed Licensing Worker (LW) by telephone.
LW was aware of the allegations but reported she had some
confusion on the matter. She reported the first safety alert the
agency received from DCWL Analyst was about a smoke alarm,
but there was already a smoke alarm in the area. She reported
the room DCWL reported concern with had all the things needed
for a bedroom. She reported on 5/12/2025 while at Foster Parent
1’s and Foster Parent 2’s home they spoke with her about
changing Child A’s room due to Child B being a noisy sleeper and
keeping Child A up at night. LW reported not being sure whether
she went down to the basement to assess the room on 5/12/2025.
She stated she had gone down to the basement space in
December 2024 when she had gone to assess this home after the
family had moved there. She reported Foster Parent 1 and Foster
Parent 2 had designed the home with extra space, and there had
not been a set purpose for the room area when the family moved
in. LW said the family made the room change to allow Child A to
obtain rest and peaceful sleep. She reported what she recalled of
the space, was it was okay and appropriate because Child A was
able to have his crib down there; there was a smoke alarm located
in the room area and outside near the steps on the main floor; a
means of egress existed by way of a sliding glass door that walks
out to the side level of the house, the patio area. LW reported she
did not think of the privacy aspect. She was looking at the fact that
the room switch would avail Child A of the ability to sleep without
being awakened by Child B ’s loud moaning/ self-soothing
technique for himself. She reported now understanding the
concern being the room where Child A is allowed to sleep
connects to the mudroom and the room can be accessed via the
garage and does not have a private entrance.
LW reported she completed a variance related to the room being
used as a bedroom, but DCWL then reported a concern with Child
A, a toddler, being in the basement. She said to correct the
matter, Foster Parent 1 and Foster Parent 2 have moved Child A
back into the bedroom with Child B.
On 6/26/2025 I interviewed Foster Parent 1 by telephone. Foster
Parent 1 confirmed information reported as to why Child A was
separated from Child B to sleep, and where his bedroom area was
relocated to. She thought moving Child A to the basement room
would be best until she and Foster Parent 2 could find another
solution. She reported once they decided to move Child A to the
basement room, they did not contact their licensing worker about
the move, because LW knew. She said LW had been in and out of
their home; that they moved to their new home prior. LW came out
4

to see the home for their address change; and they told LW Child
A would be in the basement room. Foster Parent 1 reported LW
viewed the basement area/room at that time, and did not evaluate
it as not appropriate or needing a variance.
Foster Parent 1 described their home as a three-level home with
fully finished basement and garage. She described the basement
area and room, in question for this complaint to be finished room
with a closet and there is a door with a handle at the head of the
stairs. There is also a sliding door in the room that leads outside to
a patio. There is another door that leads to the garage, which she
said, she was advised is the licensing issue/problem now. She
said if one walks in from the garage there is a room with the crib
for Child A’s bedroom, and there is a mudroom, but there is no
private entrance for Child A’s room. Foster Parent 1 affirmed
LW’s reporting they moved Child A back into the bedroom with
Child B.
Document Review:
Child A’s and Child B’s MISACWIS record which showed:
o They were placed in Foster Parent 1’s and Foster Parent
2’s foster home on 5/2/2024 and 6/9/2023 respectively.
DCWL Safety Alert dated 5/22/2025 which indicated:
o Child A is sleeping in the basement living room which has
not been assessed as a bedroom in the home.
o The agency’s response which indicated Child A was/is
sleeping in the basement and the area had been assessed
as appropriate by licensing on 5/12/2025. Additionally,
since DCWL’s concern with the basement space, on
5/29/2025, the family moved a pack and play into Child B’s
room for Child A, until the agency completes a variance for
the space. A photo of the pack and play, in place was
shown. The agency further indicated a variance had been
drafted.
Photos of the basement area which showed:
o A living room area with a crib, a sofa chair and toys on the
floor.
o A sliding glass door in the same room appeared to lead to
the outside where a trailer or camper was seen outside on
a cemented driveway.
o An area where a white door with a handle was seen near
stairs.
Floor Plan which showed by arrows pointing to/identifying:
5

o The area where a bed is identified to be located.
o A smoke alarm near the room where the bed was
identified.
o A closet under the stairs.
o A door to the upstairs
o An egress door, which was on the opposite side, away
from the room with the bed.
o A smoke alarm plus Carbon Monoxide device near the
egress door.
o An egress door/window, which appeared to be the sliding
door seen in photos, mentioned above in this area.
Foster Parent 1’s and Foster Parent 2’s 6/24/2024 reevaluation;
1/15/2025 relocation evaluation; and 7/11/2025 reevaluation which
indicated:
o During the first reevaluation Child A was in a crib in Foster
Parent 1’s and Foster Parent 2’s bedroom.
o During the relocation reevaluation the report indicated the
final bedroom had two cribs and was used for placements.
This reevaluation also indicated that down the stairs in the
basement, there is a second living room area with chairs,
workout equipment, and a sliding glass door to the side
patio of the home. Nobody was indicated to occupy a room
downstairs in the basement.
o The 7/11/2025 revaluation indicated Child A occupied a
bedroom with a crib to the east of Child B’s bedroom.
Analysis The evidence showed at the time of the complaint Child A was
being allowed to sleep in a living room area in the family’s
basement which did not meet foster home licensing requirements,
related to rest and privacy; and the agency had not requested a
variance to request an exception to the rule, nor had it initiated a
special evaluation on the foster home related to the
noncompliance. It is noteworthy that prior to the writing of this
report the agency had since initiated both.
Conclusion VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
6

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan continuation of the agency
current license status is recommended.
